Award.AwardTitle: CSBR: Living Stocks: Species validation, enhanced data access and remote archiving of the Phaff Yeast Culture Collection
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Phaff Yeast Culture Collection, at the University of California Davis, is particularly useful for basic research such as yeast physiology, yeast ecology (especially yeast-insect associations), comparative genomics, and taxonomy including discovery of new yeast species. The Phaff collection of yeasts are also used for applied research such as food and beverage fermentation, food spoilage, biofuels exploration, and the development of improved methods to identify yeasts that cause human infections. Through the activities supported in this project undergraduate students will receive training in taxonomy and molecular biology. In addition, middle school students including underrepresented groups will learn about microbiology and culture collections through presentations in the UC Davis Bio Boot Camp.

The Phaff Yeast Culture Collection is the fourth largest yeast collection in the world. It contains over 7,000 strains belonging to approximately 800 yeast species. Most strains are unique and not available from any other source. This project proposes a major overhaul of the collection to make it more useful, visible, and valuable to the worldwide yeast research and education community. This project will align the Phaff collection with comparable collections in Europe and Asia. Aims include: 1) Validate and update yeast species ID by DNA sequencing, 2) Upgrade to a more powerful database, website and online strain catalog, 3) Expand global accessibility by plugging into the Global Catalog of Microorganisms, GenBank and MycoBank, and 4) Complete the archival storage of yeasts at a remote cryopreservation facility. By posting DNA sequences of accessions in GenBank and expanding information available on the Phaff collection online catalog the collection will be more visible and valuable for all users. Lessons learned through this project will be shared with other US culture collection curators through the NSF-funded US Culture Collection Network. More information is publically available at: http://phaffcollection.ucdavis.edu.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: Yeasts are essential for production of fermented foods and beverages and biofuels, and are also important for basic research. Since 2000, five Nobel Prizes in physiology or medicine have been awarded for discoveries made using yeast as a model organism. The Phaff Yeast Culture Collection at the University of California Davis is the fourth largest yeast collection of its kind in the world, with 7500 yeast strains belonging to half the 1800 known yeast species. Most strains were isolated from natural habitats by esteemed yeast microbiologist Herman Phaff. The collection distributes strains to government agencies, universities, and industry for research in genomics, ecology, taxonomy, foods and beverages, and biotechnology. Between 1999 and 2014, curator Kyria Boundy-Mills has cryopreserved the collection, upgraded lab facilities, increased collection visibility and strain distribution, and has stored a small portion of the collection at a remote cryopreservation facility. To facilitate becoming a Biological Resource Center (BRC), additional improvements funded by this award included validating the species ID by modern methods (ribosomal DNA sequencing), remote cryostorage, and upgrading the collection database and website.

Intellectual merit: Cryopreserved stocks of 6,562 yeast strains have been prepared for storage at the USDA National Laboratory for Genetic Resources Preservation in Fort Collins, Colorado. This accomplishment is particularly timely, as raging wildfires are within 40 miles of UC Davis at the time of this writing.

Until 2014, most of the strains in the Phaff collection still carried the species name assigned by Phaff decades ago, based on traditional phenotypic characterization. Ribosomal DNA sequencing was performed on over 5,000 yeast strains, to validate species ID. While many names were simply validated, the species names were corrected for over a third of the collection, due to either the ribosomal sequence ID results or recent taxonomic revisions. DNA sequences of over 1,000 strains have been deposited in GenBank, and additional DNA sequences will be submitted in coming months. A copy of the entire catalog of 7,500 strains with updated species names was submitted to the Global Catalog of Microorganisms in early 2017.

Since 1999, the primary collection database has been in FileMaker Pro, which cannot be used for computational analyses such as phylogenetic comparisons and species ID. The online catalog has been periodically exported manually from FileMaker. In 2000-2001, over 50 years of physiological data collected in the Phaff era were entered in a database in the first version of BioloMICS, a collection management system developed by and for yeast culture collections. In this project, data was imported into the latest, greatly improved version of BioloMICS, which is currently being used by several of the top microbial collections in the world including CBS, DSMZ, CDC, and Institut Pasteur. The hosted version allows secure access for data entry and analysis, remote data backups, real-time interfacing between the strain database and the strain catalog in the hosted Phaff collection website, and linkage with other yeast collection databases. BioloMICS contains numerous useful features including a LIMS module for tracking ribosomal DNA sequencing, developed as part of a multi-million dollar Dutch government-funded project to validate 80,000 fungal strains in the CBS collection.

This funding aligned the Phaff collection services with those of comparable collections in Europe and Asia. UC Davis is a Research 1 university. Boundy-Mills has 19 years’ experience as curator of two different yeast collections, and has published extensively on yeast taxonomy, collection management, and research using and building the Phaff collection.

Broader impacts: Enhancing the quality of the collection through validation of strains and increased data access has made the collection more visible and valuable to users. DNA sequences have been used by external researchers for biogeography, comparative genomics, and taxonomy studies. Several strains were contributed to the Thousand Fungal Genomes project. Undergraduate students received training in microbiology, taxonomy and molecular biology.

The general public also has benefited through informal education events put on by the Phaff collection. Middle school students including underrepresented groups learned about microbiology and culture collections through microbiology units in the UC Davis Bio Boot Camp since 2014. Over 800 people of all ages per year have learned about microbiology, yeast, and the Phaff collection at the UC Davis Biodiversity Museum Day February 2016 and February 2017. Over 900 people learned about yeast and the Phaff collection at UC Davis Picnic Day in April 2016.

Boundy-Mills shared results of this project with other US culture collection curators through the NSF-funded US Culture Collection Network, and with international culture collections through her role as member of the executive board of the World Federation of Culture Collections. The improvements to the database helped the collection to adhere to recommendations of the Nagoya Protocol of the Convention on Biological Diversity.
